# Project: Investigate the IMDB Movies Dataset ## Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Data Wrangling
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Conclusions

## Introduction In this project, I will go through the data analysis process through working on a movies dataset from IMDB. This project is part of Udacity's Data Analyst Nanodegree. ### My research questions about this dataset are: 1. Who are the actors with largest number of movies? 2. What is the effect of number of votes on movie rating average? 3. What are the longest and shortest types of movies? 4. What type of movies are being produced every year? What are the most produced movies back in 1960 and in 2015? 5. How is the profit of Movie iIndustry changing through the years?

# Import required libraries
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
%matplotlib inline
## Data Wrangling In this section, data will be loaded and cleaned o start the analysis

### Data Cleaning

After a quick look on the data, there some cleaning to be made:
- Remove unneeded columns: (`homepage`, `overview`, `tagline`)
- Remove rows containing null values
- Convert the `release_date` column from String to DateTime object

source:
# Remove unneeded columns
df_original.drop('homepage', axis=1, inplace=True)
df_original.drop('overview', axis=1, inplace=True)
df_original.drop('tagline', axis=1, inplace=True)

# Remove rows with null values
df_original.dropna(inplace=True)

# Convert the release_date column from String to DateTime object
df_original.release_date = pd.to_datetime(df_original.release_date)

# Check the results of data cleaning
df_original.info()

## Exploratory Data Analysis > Before exploring the dataset, there is useful finction I want to use. Since there are some columns with cells containing multiple values such as: `genres` and `cast`, we need to have a way to split these values into different cells to make it easy on us to analyze. This code below does just that. It was taken from the link below on stackoverflow website. [# https://gist.github.com/jlln/338b4b0b55bd6984f883]: https://gist.github.com/jlln/338b4b0b55bd6984f883

# This function was taken from here
# https://gist.github.com/jlln/338b4b0b55bd6984f883

def splitDataFrameList(df,target_column,separator):
    ''' df = dataframe to split,
    target_column = the column containing the values to split
    separator = the symbol used to perform the split

    returns: a dataframe with each entry for the target column separated, with each element moved into a new row. 
    The values in the other columns are duplicated across the newly divided rows.
    '''
    def splitListToRows(row,row_accumulator,target_column,separator):
        split_row = row[target_column].split(separator)
        for s in split_row:
            new_row = row.to_dict()
            new_row[target_column] = s
            row_accumulator.append(new_row)
    new_rows = []
    df.apply(splitListToRows,axis=1,args = (new_rows,target_column,separator))
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(new_rows)
    return new_df
### Research Question 1: Who are the actors with largest number of movies?

# First we use the function above to split actors into multiple rows.
df_cast_expanded = splitDataFrameList(df_original, "cast", "|")

# Then, we gat a list of top 10 actors with larget number of movies they participated in
most_active_actors = df_cast_expanded.groupby("cast")["cast"].count().sort_values(ascending=False).head(10)

# Start plotting
plt.figure()
most_active_actors_plot = most_active_actors.plot(kind="bar", title="Most Active Actors", figsize=(15,8));
plt.xlabel("Actors")
plt.ylabel("# of movies")

# This loop below to add value labels above the bars is taken from stackoverflow
# https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25447700/annotate-bars-with-values-on-pandas-bar-plots
for p in most_active_actors_plot.patches:
    most_active_actors_plot.annotate(str(p.get_height()), (p.get_x() + p.get_width()/2 - 0.08, p.get_height() * 1.01))

plt.show()

source: most_active_actors
### Research Question 2: What is the effect of number of votes on movie rating average?

# Compare votes count with average rating
plt.figure()
vote_vs_rating_plt = df_original.plot(x="vote_average", y="vote_count", title="Effect of # of votes on rating", kind="scatter");

plt.xlabel("Movie Rating")
plt.ylabel("# of votes")

plt.show()

As shown in the graph above, movies with higher rating tend to have more votes as more people watch them. We actually see this in real life; people sometimes watch movies based on movies rating so these movies get attention and in turn more votes.
## Research Question 3: What are the longest and shortest types of movies?

# First we split genres into multiple rows.
df_genres_expanded = splitDataFrameList(df_original, "genres", "|")

# Then, we group by genres and find out the average run_time for every type of movie
genres_runtime = df_genres_expanded.groupby("genres")["runtime"].mean().sort_values(ascending=True)

# Start plotting
plt.figure()
genres_runtime_plot = genres_runtime.plot(kind="barh", title="Average Runtime of movies per genre", figsize=(16,8));
plt.xlabel("Movie Genre")
plt.ylabel("Runtime in minutes")

for p in genres_runtime_plot.patches:
    genres_runtime_plot.annotate(str(round(p.get_width(), 2)), (p.get_width() + 0.5, p.get_y() + 0.1))

plt.show()

It is pretty obvious from the graph that History and War movies are usually the longest while Animation movies are the shortest by almost half the duration. 

## Research Question 4: What type of movies are being produced every year?

# First, we use the expanded genres table, so we can group our data by release year and genres
df_year_genres = df_genres_expanded.groupby(["release_year", "genres"])["release_year"].count().unstack()

# Plot the results
plt.figure()
df_year_genres.plot(kind="area", stacked=True, figsize=(16,12), colormap="tab20c")
plt.xlabel("Movie Release Year")
plt.ylabel("Number of movies")
df_genres_expanded.groupby(["release_year", "genres"])["release_year"].count().unstack()

From the graph above, we see that movies were popular back in 1960 were Action, Drama. These two types of movies got even more popular along with other types such as: Thriller, Comedy and History

In addition, there is a clear big jump in number of prodcued movies per year between 2005 and 2007 and also 2012.

## Research Question 5: How is the profit of Movie iIndustry changing through the years?
In order for us to calculate this accurately, we need to look at the data again.

> **Note**: There are some movies with zero budget, this does not make sense and they need to be removed from the dataset

source: df_original.query("budget == 0").head()
As shown in the query results above, there are 3938 movies with **zero** budget. All these movies will be removed before calculating movies industry profit through years.

text/plain: Text(0,0.5,'Movies adjusted revenue in Billion dollars')

source:
# Get all non-zero budget movies
df_nonzero_budget = df_original[df_original.budget != 0]

# Group resulted dataset by release_year and find the adjusted revenue value in billions
profit_years_in_B = df_nonzero_budget.groupby("release_year")["revenue_adj"].sum()/1000000000

# Plot the results
plt.figure()
profit_years_in_B.plot(kind="line", figsize=(16,8), grid=True);
plt.xlabel("Movie Release Year")
plt.ylabel("Movies adjusted revenue in Billion dollars")
We can see from the graph above that the movie industry is becoming more and more profiting. In just 55 years, the movie industry revenue **doubled about 12 times!!**

## Conclusions Sine we reached the end of our analysis, here is a quick summary of our observations: 1. Most active actors with 50+ movies are: - Robert De Niro, Samuel L. Jackson, Bruce Willis, Nicolas Cage, Michael Caine 2. Movies with higher rating tend to have more votes as more people tend to watch them. 3. History and War movies are usually the longest while Animation movies are the shortest by almost half the duration. 4. movies were popular back in 1960 were Action, Drama. These two types of movies got even more popular along with other types such as: Thriller, Comedy and History. 5. There is a clear big jump in number of prodcued movies per year between 2005 and 2007 and also 2012. 6. the movie industry is becoming more and more profiting. In just 55 years, the movie industry revenue doubled about 12 times!!
